author: Will Healy
content: The decision by Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway (BRK.A 1.07%)(BRK.B 0.53%) to buy Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing(TSM 0.17%), better known as TSMC, and then sell most of that stock a short time later may have investors scratching their heads. TSMC is a critical component in many of the technologies that are essential to modern life. In fact, its chips can be found in everything from smartphones to artificial intelligence servers. So, how should investors interpret this move?
description: Risk tolerance is a factor for both Taiwan Semiconductor's stock and the stocks of its clients.
title: How Investors Should React to Warren Buffett's Sale of Taiwan Semiconductor Stock - The Motley Fool

author: Ali B.
content: Bitcoin and Ethereum, two of the largest digital currencies, have been making headlines lately as their values continue to rise. It has recently surpassed the $30,000 mark, while Ethereum, which is the second-largest cryptocurrency by market capitalization, hit an all-time high of $2,500. With a market cap of over $1.2 trillion, Bitcoin is the largest cryptocurrency by far, but what does the future hold for these digital assets?

author: Kana Inagaki, David Sheppard, Andy Bounds
content:
G7 countries have pledged to accelerate a gradual phaseout of fossil fuels and the shift towards renewable energy, as Japan faced significant pushback on key pillars of its climate strategy.
The agreement, signed off at a meeting in London of G7 energy ministers, also included commitments to boost investment in green energy and support developing countries decarbonise.
Japan was the only country that did not commit to phasing out new coal plants at the meeting, but said it would only consider ammonia as a transitional fuel under certain conditions.
description: Japan’s plans for ammonia and coal use challenged but Tokyo resists setting firm timeline for wind down
title: G7 ministers agree to speed up phaseout of fossil fuels - Financial Times
